newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan offers sale of electricity firm.
newsitem.headline: Jordan offers sale of electricity firm.

text.p: Jordan is offering foreign investors linked to a local partner up to 51 percent of Irbid Electricity Company (IDECO), the country's second largest electricity distribution firm, officials said on Tuesday.

The state-owned National Electric Power Company, which owns 55 percent of the publicly listed firm, has invited interested foreign and local investors to submit expressions of interest by September 15, 1997.

Officials at the National Electric Power Company, which is handling the transaction, said that they expected the sale to be completed by year-end. Financial proposals would be requested in October after shortlisting the firms, they said.

IDECO which has assets of 52 million dinars ($73 million) holds a concession to distribute electricity in nearly 30 percent of the country, covering Irbid, Ajloun, Jerash and Mefraq governates and an unutilised license to generate electricity.
The foreign investor must acquire the shares through a consortium with a local firm which would have a minimum 10 percent participation, they said.
IDECO's electricity supply rose 11.5 percent in 1996 to 642 kilowatts and sales turnover rose to $32 million from $26.8 million.
The firm has a private 11 percent private sector shareholding while 34 percent is owned by the municipalities
The government was looking primarily for a strategic partner in the power industry or a financial investor who could procure industry expertise, officials said.
